info.game_comments:
WE ASKED: Ballerina Misty Copeland.

Alex uses a cane during the closing credits chat.

(1, 1).clue: Items that sell quickly & in great quantity are said to "go like" these

(2, 1).clue: Groupon cofounder Andrew Mason explained, "It's short for" these 2 words

(3, 1).clue: This phrase of protest coined by Alicia Garza has become a hashtag & a movement

(4, 1).clue: Just before "mansion" in the dictionary is this mansion, the main house on an estate

(6, 1).clue: It was the capital of Prussia before it was the capital of Germany

(1, 2).clue: It's the distinctive column of smoke & debris seen over a nuclear explosion

(2, 2).clue: This web-based e-mail service got its name by adding some vowels to "HTML"

(3, 2).clue: (I'm Misty Copeland.)  In 2014 I made history as the first African-American ballerina to dance the role of Clara in American Ballet Theatre's production of this ballet, a holiday favorite

(4, 2).clue: With or without ghosts, a place regularly visited or inhabited can be called by this "scary" name

(6, 2).clue: Appropriately, a house where this theologian once lived in Wittenberg is now a Reformation museum

(1, 3).clue: This expression of contentment can be followed with "at high tide"
(1, 3).correct response: happy as a clam at high tide

(2, 3).clue: A vendor for this Neil Clark Warren website suggested its name, reflecting its users' search online for compatibility

(3, 3).clue: Beginning in 1867 school was in session for what is now Morehouse College & this university in Washington, D.C.

(4, 3).clue: A popular type of living space; the 1960 Jack Lemmon movie of that title won 5 Oscars

(6, 3).clue: Oak, beech & fir trees are in this forest region of southwestern Germany that borders Basel

(1, 4).clue: A condiment is included in this 3-word phrase meaning "to meet or succeed the standard"

(2, 4).clue: It got its name by removing the first 3 letters from the name of the horse that Bellerophon tried to fly to heaven

(3, 4).clue: Porter on the train cars named for him was a good middle-class job, though you got called "George" whatever your name was

(4, 4).clue: Before the man cave, there was this space for an unmarried guy, as in the title of an "Ultra-Lounge" CD

(6, 4).clue: An industrial region of Germany is named for this 146-mile "r"iver, a tributary of the Rhine

(1, 5).clue: Boxing & wrestling are risk factors for this condition, though it can also be caused by high piercings

(2, 5).clue: The "PE" at the end of this service around since 2003 stands for peer-to-peer

(3, 5).clue: 2013 saw the first Congress with 2 African-American senators when Mo Cowan of Mass. served with Tim Scott of this state

(4, 5).clue: The presidential retreat today known as Camp David was first named this by FDR after a James Hilton novel

(6, 5).clue: Destroyed in a terrifying 1945 air raid, this city's best-known church was rebuilt & reopened 60 years later

(1, 1).clue: This game from Rovio has been downloaded more than 2 billion times

(2, 1).clue: This brand is named for a real doctor, the grandson of a cobbler who got his medical degree in 1904

(3, 1).clue: The quiet joys of fishing are described in Izaak Walton's 1653 work "The Compleat" this

(4, 1).clue: Quit moving these, which support the crossbars on a football field

(5, 1).clue: In the 1700s William Stukeley was the first to recognize that the objects of this British site were aligned on the solstices

(6, 1).clue: First Lady Mary Lincoln:This couple, Robert & Eliza

(1, 2).clue: This TV series was based on Chris Rock's childhood

(2, 2).clue: The Salish language gives us this other name for Bigfoot

(3, 2).clue: On Dec. 9, 1854, just 45 days after the event, The Examiner published this Tennyson poem

(4, 2).clue: Hyphenated term for an aggressively enterprising person

(5, 2).clue: 18th century archaeologists uncovered the Villa of the Papyri, an ancient library, in this neighbor to Pompeii

(6, 2).clue: Mary I:Henry VIII & this Spanish import

(1, 3).clue: In vaudeville, future "I Love Lucy" co-star William Frawley helped popularize the song about this sad "baby"

(2, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew shows an anatomical diagram on the monitor.)  Wearing flat shoes like flip-flops can lead to a lack of arch support and a stabbing pain in the heel caused by inflammation of the thick band of tissue along the bottom of the foot, a condition known as this fasciitis

(3, 3).clue: This 1895 H.G. Wells book was subtitled "An Invention"

(4, 3).clue: Colorful term for the winning score in an overtime soccer match

(5, 3).clue: In 1970 the wreck of the El Gran Grifon, part of this fleet, was found off Scotland 382 years after it sank

(6, 3).clue: Mary who painted "The Boating Party" in the 1890s:This banker & his wife Katherine

(1, 4).clue: The '80s group New Order rose from the ashes of this British post-punk band

(2, 4).clue: To do this soccer kick, you throw both feet in the air & kick the airborne ball toward the goal behind you

(3, 4).clue: The subject of 52 G.K. Chesterton stories, this cleric had a simple face "as round and dull as a Norfolk dumpling"

(4, 4).clue: Land o' this pastoral part of lower Egypt

(5, 4).clue: 3rd c. Roman soldiers found near sulfur crystals were apparently early victims of this type of warfare

(6, 4).clue: Mary, Queen of Scots:Mary of Guise & this Scottish king V

(1, 5).clue: Javier Bardem starred in the movie adaptation of this Gabriel Garcia Marquez novel
(1, 5).correct response: Love in the Time of Cholera

(3, 5).clue: Dickens' artist Luke Fildes said Dickens told him the solution to this was that John Jasper strangled his nephew

(4, 5).clue: For the tangles of knots it sometimes forms, a species of nematomorph is called this worm

(5, 5).clue: Robert Koldewey began excavating this 8th gate of Babylon; it was reconstructed at the Pergamon Museum in Berlin

(0, 0).clue: In 2014 it was No. 1 in Sweden &, thanks to an animated movie, in the top 300 for U.S. baby girls for the first time in decades
